words.definition: Very old; from a long time ago.
sentences: Ancient civilizations built amazing temples.
We learned about ancient Egypt in school.
The museum displayed many ancient tools.

words.definition: A society with its own culture, laws, and way of life.
sentences: The Mayan civilization had a complex writing system.
Many great civilizations have existed throughout history.
The discovery of farming helped early civilizations grow.

words.definition: A large area of land or many countries ruled by one powerful leader or government.
sentences: The Roman Empire was very powerful and large.
Many different groups lived within the empire.
The emperor controlled a vast empire.

words.definition: A series of rulers from the same family.
sentences: The Ming Dynasty ruled China for many years.
Each dynasty had its own special art style.
The new dynasty brought peace to the land.

words.definition: A country where citizens choose their leaders through voting.
sentences: The United States is a republic.
In a republic, the people have a say in government.
Ancient Rome started as a republic.

words.definition: A system of government where the people have the power, often by voting.
sentences: Democracy allows everyone to vote for their leaders.
Freedom of speech is important in a democracy.
Many countries today aim for a democracy.

words.definition: A system of government where a king or queen rules.
sentences: Some countries still have a monarchy.
The queen inherited the throne in the monarchy.
In a monarchy, power often passes down in a family.

words.definition: A government where one person has total power and control.
sentences: Life can be very strict under a dictatorship.
People have few freedoms in a dictatorship.
The dictator made all the decisions in the dictatorship.

words.definition: The group of people who rule a country or state.
sentences: The government makes laws for the country.
Citizens vote for their government leaders.
The local government takes care of the city.

words.definition: A person who legally belongs to a country.
sentences: Every citizen has rights and responsibilities.
As a citizen, you can vote in elections.
She became a citizen after living there for many years.

words.definition: To choose a leader or a decision by marking a ballot.
sentences: It's important to vote in every election.
We will vote for the new school president.
Every vote counts in a democracy.

words.definition: The process of choosing leaders by voting.
sentences: The election for mayor happens next month.
Candidates give speeches before the election.
The results of the election were announced last night.

words.definition: A rule made by the government that everyone must follow.
sentences: It is against the law to steal.
The new law helps protect the environment.
Police enforce the law.

words.definition: A set of basic laws and principles that a country is governed by.
sentences: The Constitution protects our rights.
Every country has its own constitution.
The new amendment was added to the constitution.

words.definition: A country or area controlled by another, more powerful country.
sentences: India was once a British colony.
Many European countries had colonies around the world.
The settlers established a new colony.

words.definition: Freedom from the control of another country or person.
sentences: The country fought for its independence.
They celebrated their Independence Day every year.
Achieving independence was a long struggle.

words.definition: A conflict between two or more countries or groups, usually involving fighting.
sentences: The war lasted for many years.
Soldiers fought bravely in the war.
Many lives are lost during a war.

words.definition: A time when there is no war or fighting; calm and quiet.
sentences: After the war, the country enjoyed a period of peace.
We all hope for world peace.
The treaty brought peace between the two nations.

words.definition: A formal agreement between two or more countries.
sentences: The two countries signed a peace treaty.
The treaty ended the war.
Diplomats worked hard to create the treaty.

words.definition: A serious disagreement or argument, often leading to fighting.
sentences: There was a conflict over land ownership.
The conflict between the two groups lasted for years.
They tried to resolve the conflict peacefully.

words.definition: A public expression of disagreement or disapproval.
sentences: Many people joined the protest against the new law.
The students organized a peaceful protest.
The protest aimed to raise awareness.

words.definition: A person who guides or directs a group or country.
sentences: The president is the leader of the country.
A good leader listens to their people.
She was chosen as the team leader.

words.definition: A person who works in politics, especially as an elected official.
sentences: The politician gave a speech about new policies.
He wants to become a politician when he grows up.
Politicians represent the people.

words.definition: A group of elected people who make laws in some countries.
sentences: The new law was debated in parliament.
Members of parliament represent different areas.
Parliament meets to discuss important issues.

words.definition: The elected head of a republic.
sentences: The president lives in the White House.
The president gave a speech to the nation.
He ran for president in the last election.

words.definition: The head of the government in some countries with a parliament.
sentences: The Prime Minister announced new plans for education.
She met with the Prime Minister to discuss the issue.
The Prime Minister leads the ruling party.

words.definition: A group of important government ministers chosen by the leader.
sentences: The president met with his cabinet members.
The cabinet discusses important national issues.
Each member of the cabinet has a specific role.

words.definition: A plan of action or set of rules agreed upon by a government or group.
sentences: The government introduced a new economic policy.
The school has a strict no-bullying policy.
They debated the new foreign policy.

words.definition: Fairness in the way people are treated.
sentences: Everyone deserves justice.
The court seeks to ensure justice for all.
They fought for social justice.

words.definition: Things that people are allowed to have or do, protected by law.
sentences: All citizens have basic human rights.
The right to vote is an important right.
They protested for equal rights.

words.definition: The state of being free; not controlled by others.
sentences: People fought for their freedom.
Freedom of speech is important in a democracy.
He enjoyed the freedom of traveling alone.

words.definition: The state of being equal, especially in rights, status, or opportunities.
sentences: They believe in equality for all people.
The movement fought for gender equality.
Equality means everyone is treated the same.

words.definition: The state of being extremely poor.
sentences: Many organizations work to reduce poverty.
Poverty can affect education and health.
The government aims to fight poverty.

words.definition: A large amount of money or valuable possessions.
sentences: The country has great natural wealth.
He inherited a large amount of wealth.
Wealth can provide many opportunities.

words.definition: The movement of people from one place to another to live.
sentences: There has been a lot of migration to the cities.
Economic reasons often cause migration.
Bird migration happens every year.

words.definition: The process of more and more people moving to cities.
sentences: Urbanization leads to larger cities.
Many countries are experiencing rapid urbanization.
Urbanization can create new challenges.

words.definition: The process of countries becoming more connected through trade, culture, and technology.
sentences: Globalization has made the world feel smaller.
The internet has sped up globalization.
Globalization affects economies worldwide.

words.definition: Basic rights and freedoms that all people should have.
sentences: The organization works to protect human rights.
Freedom of speech is a human right.
Violations of human rights are a serious concern.

words.definition: A person who works to bring about political or social change.
sentences: She is an activist for environmental protection.
The activist organized a rally.
Many young people are becoming activists.

words.definition: Information, often biased or misleading, used to promote a political cause or point of view.
sentences: The government used propaganda to influence public opinion.
Propaganda posters were seen everywhere.
It's important to recognize propaganda.

words.definition: The suppression of speech, public communication, or other information that may be considered objectionable.
sentences: Some countries practice strict censorship of the media.
Censorship limits what people can see and read.
Artists often fight against censorship.

words.definition: A sudden, illegal, and often violent change of government.
sentences: The military staged a coup to take power.
News reported a coup in the small country.
The coup led to political instability.

words.definition: The murder of an important person, usually for political reasons.
sentences: The assassination of the leader shocked the nation.
History records many political assassinations.
The police investigated the assassination.

words.definition: The right to vote in political elections.
sentences: Women fought for suffrage for many years.
Universal suffrage means everyone can vote.
The movement for suffrage gained strength.

words.definition: The act of officially ending something, especially slavery.
sentences: The abolition of slavery was a major step forward.
Abolitionists worked hard to end the practice.
The law led to the abolition of the tax.

words.definition: A period of major changes in how goods were made, using machines.
sentences: The Industrial Revolution began in Great Britain.
It changed society and work forever.
New factories appeared during the Industrial Revolution.

words.definition: A period in history when people began to use reason and science to understand the world.
sentences: The Enlightenment brought new ideas about government.
Thinkers of the Enlightenment questioned old traditions.
Many modern ideas came from the Enlightenment.

words.definition: A social system in medieval Europe where land was exchanged for military service.
sentences: Feudalism was common in the Middle Ages.
Lords and vassals were part of the feudalism system.
The system of feudalism shaped medieval society.

words.definition: A series of religious wars fought by European Christians to reclaim the Holy Land.
sentences: The Crusades lasted for many centuries.
Knights went on the Crusades.
The Crusades had a big impact on Europe and the Middle East.

words.definition: A period of great new art, science, and learning in Europe after the Middle Ages.
sentences: The Renaissance began in Italy.
Many famous artists lived during the Renaissance.
The Renaissance was a time of rebirth in culture.

words.definition: A 16th-century movement that led to the creation of Protestant churches.
sentences: The Reformation changed Christianity in Europe.
Martin Luther was a key figure in the Reformation.
The Reformation had political and religious effects.

words.definition: The act of traveling to new places to discover them.
sentences: The Age of Exploration led to new discoveries.
Exploration of space continues today.
Early explorers faced many dangers during their exploration.

words.definition: The process of one country taking control of another area and settling its people there.
sentences: European colonization had a big impact on many continents.
Colonization often led to conflict with native peoples.
The history of colonization is complex.

words.definition: The process of a colony becoming independent from its ruling country.
sentences: Many African countries went through decolonization after World War II.
Decolonization often involved struggles for freedom.
The era of decolonization reshaped the world map.

words.definition: A period of political tension and rivalry between the US and the Soviet Union after WWII, without direct fighting.
sentences: The Cold War lasted for many decades.
It was a time of great fear and suspicion.
The fall of the Berlin Wall marked the end of the Cold War.

words.definition: A group of countries that have signed a formal agreement to work together.
sentences: NATO is a well-known treaty organization.
Members of a treaty organization agree to mutual defense.
The treaty organization aimed to maintain stability.

words.definition: A meeting between heads of government.
sentences: The leaders held a summit to discuss climate change.
Important decisions are often made at a summit.
The international summit brought world leaders together.

words.definition: Official orders or laws stopping trade or contact with a country to make it change its policies.
sentences: Economic sanctions were placed on the country.
The UN imposed sanctions on the rogue state.
Sanctions can hurt a country's economy.

words.definition: An official ban on trade or other commercial activity with a particular country.
sentences: The country placed an embargo on oil exports.
An embargo can be used as a political tool.
The trade embargo affected many businesses.

words.definition: A tax to be paid on a particular class of imports or exports.
sentences: The government imposed a tariff on imported goods.
Tariffs can make foreign products more expensive.
They debated the new trade tariff.

words.definition: A plan of how money will be spent and how it will be obtained.
sentences: The government presented its annual budget.
We need to stick to our family budget.
The new budget includes funding for schools.

words.definition: Money that people or businesses must pay to the government.
sentences: We pay tax on our income.
The government uses tax money for public services.
There's a new tax on luxury items.

words.definition: The health, happiness, and fortunes of a person or group; also, government aid to the poor.
sentences: The government provides welfare programs for those in need.
The welfare of the children is our top priority.
They discussed reforms to the welfare system.

words.definition: Services provided by the government to the public, like healthcare or education.
sentences: Doctors and teachers work in public service.
Public service is important for a healthy society.
He dedicated his life to public service.

words.definition: The basic physical and organizational structures and facilities needed for the operation of a society or enterprise.
sentences: Good roads and bridges are part of a country's infrastructure.
The government plans to invest in infrastructure.
Damaged infrastructure can cause major problems.

words.definition: Relating to a city or town.
sentences: Many people live in urban areas.
Urban planning helps cities grow well.
The urban landscape is changing rapidly.

words.definition: Relating to the countryside, not the city.
sentences: Life in rural areas is often quieter.
Many farms are located in rural regions.
She grew up in a small rural village.

words.definition: A person who has been forced to leave their country because of war, persecution, or natural disaster.
sentences: Many refugees sought safety in neighboring countries.
The organization helps refugees find new homes.
The camp provided shelter for thousands of refugees.

words.definition: A person who comes to live permanently in a foreign country.
sentences: Many immigrants contribute to their new country's economy.
Her grandparents were immigrants from Europe.
The city has a diverse immigrant population.

words.definition: A person who leaves their own country in order to settle permanently in another.
sentences: Many young people become emigrants seeking better opportunities.
The country saw a large number of emigrants last year.
He was an emigrant from Ireland.

words.definition: The deliberate killing of a large group of people, especially those of a particular ethnic group or nation.
sentences: The world must work to prevent genocide.
Genocide is a terrible crime against humanity.
The historical event was recognized as a genocide.

words.definition: The avoidance of excess or extremes; a balanced approach.
sentences: In politics, moderation can help find common ground.
He always spoke with moderation and reason.
Moderation is key to a healthy lifestyle.

words.definition: General agreement among a group of people.
sentences: They reached a consensus on the new policy.
It was hard to build a consensus among all parties.
The decision was made by consensus.

words.definition: The study of human history and prehistory through the excavation of sites and the analysis of artifacts.
sentences: Archaeology helps us understand ancient cultures.
They found old pottery during the archaeology dig.
She is studying archaeology at university.

words.definition: An object made by a human being, typically an item of cultural or historical interest.
sentences: The museum displayed ancient artifacts.
They discovered a rare artifact from the Stone Age.
Each artifact tells a story about the past.

words.definition: The arrangement of events or dates in the order of their occurrence.
sentences: The history book presented events in chronological order.
Understanding the chronology of events is important.
The detective tried to establish the chronology of the crime.

words.definition: A long and distinct period of history.
sentences: The Victorian Era was a time of great change.
We are living in a digital era.
The discovery marked a new era in science.

words.definition: A period of ten years.
sentences: The 1980s were a fun decade for music.
The project will take a decade to complete.
The city has changed a lot in the past decade.

words.definition: A period of one hundred years.
sentences: The 20th century saw two world wars.
This building is over a century old.
Art styles changed greatly over the last century.

words.definition: A period of one thousand years.
sentences: The year 2000 marked the start of a new millennium.
Ancient history covers several millennia.
The tree has stood for over a millennium.

words.definition: A person who studies and writes about the past.
sentences: The historian wrote a book about the Roman Empire.
Historians use old documents to learn about the past.
She wants to become a historian.

words.definition: An original document or object from the time period being studied.
sentences: Diaries and letters are primary sources.
Historians rely on primary sources for their research.
The old map was a valuable primary source.

words.definition: A document or object that discusses information originally presented elsewhere.
sentences: A textbook is a secondary source.
She used a secondary source for her essay.
Secondary sources often analyze primary sources.

words.definition: The improvement or amendment of what is wrong, corrupt, or unsatisfactory.
sentences: The government promised to reform the education system.
Many people called for political reform.
The new leader introduced several reforms.

words.definition: The skill of managing international relations, typically by a country's representatives abroad.
sentences: Diplomacy is important for solving international problems.
He is skilled in diplomacy and negotiation.
They used diplomacy to avoid war.

words.definition: An official representative of a country in another country.
sentences: The ambassador lives in the embassy.
She was appointed as the new ambassador to France.
The ambassador works to improve relations between nations.

words.definition: The system by which a country's money, industry, and trade are organized.
sentences: The country's economy is growing rapidly.
A strong economy provides jobs for people.
The global economy affects everyone.

words.definition: A political and economic theory where the community owns and controls the means of production.
sentences: Socialism often emphasizes equality and social welfare.
Some countries have elements of socialism in their policies.
The debate between capitalism and socialism is ongoing.

words.definition: An economic system where private individuals or businesses own most of the means of production.
sentences: Capitalism encourages competition and innovation.
Many Western countries operate under capitalism.
The free market is a key feature of capitalism.

words.definition: A strong feeling of pride in and devotion to one's country.
sentences: Nationalism can unite people but also cause conflict.
The rise of nationalism led to new nations.
Extreme nationalism can be dangerous.

words.definition: A system of government by one person with absolute power.
sentences: The country was ruled by an autocracy.
In an autocracy, the leader has unlimited power.
Many ancient kingdoms were autocracies.

words.definition: A small group of people having control of a country or organization.
sentences: Some countries are governed by an oligarchy.
Power was concentrated in the hands of a few in the oligarchy.
The wealthy elite formed an oligarchy.

words.definition: A state of disorder due to absence or non-recognition of authority.
sentences: Without laws, society could fall into anarchy.
The collapse of the government led to anarchy.
Anarchy is a state of lawlessness.

words.definition: Relating to a system of government in which several states form a unity but remain independent in internal affairs.
sentences: The United States has a federal government.
Federal laws apply to the entire country.
Each state has its own government, but also a federal one.

words.definition: A nation or territory considered as an organized political community under one government.
sentences: The state has its own capital city.
He is a head of state.
Many states joined the union.

words.definition: A principal administrative division of certain countries or empires.
sentences: Canada is divided into provinces.
Each province has its own local government.
The ancient empire had many provinces.

words.definition: A geographical and political subdivision of a state or country.
sentences: The county fair is held every summer.
She lives in the next county over.
The county government manages local services.

words.definition: A city or town that has its own local government.
sentences: The municipality is responsible for waste collection.
Each municipality has its own mayor.
The new park was built by the municipality.

words.definition: The elected head of a city or town.
sentences: The mayor announced plans for new public transport.
She is running for mayor next year.
The mayor attended the community event.

words.definition: The elected head of a state or province.
sentences: The governor signed the new bill into law.
He served as governor for two terms.
The governor addressed the state's concerns.

words.definition: A member of a senate.
sentences: The senator debated the new policy.
She hopes to become a senator one day.
Senators represent their states in government.

words.definition: A national legislative body, especially that of the US.
sentences: Congress passed the new law.
Members of Congress meet in Washington D.C.
The issue was debated in Congress for weeks.

words.definition: Laws, considered collectively.
sentences: New legislation was introduced to protect privacy.
The government is working on new environmental legislation.
This legislation will affect many people.

words.definition: A constitutional right to reject a decision or proposal made by a law-making body.
sentences: The president can veto a bill.
The governor used his power to veto the legislation.
The bill passed despite the threat of a veto.

words.definition: A minor change or addition designed to improve a text, piece of legislation, etc.
sentences: An amendment was added to the constitution.
They proposed an amendment to the law.
The amendment changed the original meaning slightly.

words.definition: The official residence or offices of an ambassador.
sentences: He works at the American embassy in London.
The embassy is a safe place for citizens abroad.
She visited the embassy to renew her passport.

words.definition: The place or building in which a consul's duties are carried out.
sentences: The consulate helps citizens with visas.
He went to the consulate for assistance.
The consulate is smaller than an embassy.

words.definition: An official representing a country abroad.
sentences: The diplomat worked to resolve the crisis.
She is a skilled diplomat.
Diplomats play a key role in international relations.

words.definition: Discussion aimed at reaching an agreement.
sentences: The negotiation between the two sides was difficult.
They entered into negotiation to end the conflict.
Successful negotiation requires compromise.

words.definition: A union or association formed for mutual benefit, especially between countries or organizations.
sentences: The countries formed a military alliance.
Their alliance helped them achieve their goals.
The new alliance strengthened their position.

words.definition: A political party or group that is against the government in power.
sentences: The opposition criticized the new policy.
The leader of the opposition spoke in parliament.
The opposition party wants to win the next election.

words.definition: The political party or parties that form the government.
sentences: The ruling party won the most seats in the election.
The ruling party introduced new reforms.
The policies of the ruling party affect everyone.

words.definition: Having two branches or chambers, as in a legislative body.
sentences: The US Congress is a bicameral legislature.
Many democracies have a bicameral parliament.
A bicameral system provides checks and balances.

words.definition: Having a single legislative chamber.
sentences: Some smaller countries have a unicameral parliament.
A unicameral system can be faster for making laws.
Nebraska is the only U.S. state with a unicameral legislature.

words.definition: A direct vote by the people on a particular proposal or law.
sentences: The people voted in a referendum on the new constitution.
A referendum was held to decide the issue.
The results of the referendum were very close.

words.definition: A direct vote of all the members of an electorate on an important public question.
sentences: The government held a plebiscite on the border dispute.
A plebiscite is similar to a referendum.
The plebiscite showed strong public support.

words.definition: An official pardon for people who have committed political offenses.
sentences: The government granted amnesty to political prisoners.
A general amnesty was declared after the civil war.
Amnesty International works for human rights.

words.definition: A sudden, violent, and illegal seizure of power from a government.
sentences: The military staged a coup d'Ã©tat.
News reported a coup d'Ã©tat in the capital.
The coup d'Ã©tat led to a change in leadership.

words.definition: An attempt to put an end to the authority of a person or body by rebelling.
sentences: The people decided to revolt against the harsh ruler.
The peasants' revolt was quickly put down.
News of the revolt spread quickly.

words.definition: An act of resistance or rebellion against authority or an established government.
sentences: The people's uprising led to the fall of the dictator.
There was a small uprising in the city.
The uprising was a cry for freedom.

words.definition: The advocacy or practice of separation of a certain group of people from a larger body on the basis of ethnicity, religion, or gender.
sentences: The region had a strong movement for separatism.
Separatism can lead to political instability.
They debated the issue of separatism in parliament.

words.definition: The action of withdrawing formally from membership of a federation or body, especially a political state.
sentences: The southern states declared their secession from the Union.
The threat of secession led to civil war.
The region voted on secession from the country.

words.definition: The action of annexing something, especially territory.
sentences: The powerful country completed the annexation of the smaller territory.
The annexation led to protests from other nations.
Historical records show the annexation occurred peacefully.

words.definition: Supreme power or authority; the authority of a state to govern itself.
sentences: The country declared its sovereignty.
National sovereignty is a key principle in international law.
They fought to protect their sovereignty.

words.definition: The right or condition of self-government.
sentences: The region was granted greater autonomy.
Local communities often seek more autonomy.
The university has a high degree of autonomy.

words.definition: A system of government in which power is divided between a central authority and individual states or provinces.
sentences: Federalism allows states to make some of their own laws.
The country's government is based on federalism.
Federalism balances power between different levels.

words.definition: A state governed as a single power in which the central government is ultimately supreme.
sentences: France is an example of a unitary state.
In a unitary state, local governments have less power.
Most countries in the world are unitary states.

words.definition: An organization that consists of a number of parties or groups united in an alliance or league.
sentences: The early American states formed a confederation.
A confederation gives more power to individual states.
The sports clubs formed a new confederation.

words.definition: A monarchy where the ruler has total, unlimited power.
sentences: Saudi Arabia is an example of an absolute monarchy.
In an absolute monarchy, the king's word is law.
The people have no say in an absolute monarchy.

words.definition: A monarchy where the monarch's power is limited by a constitution.
sentences: The United Kingdom is a constitutional monarchy.
In a constitutional monarchy, the monarch has ceremonial duties.
The constitution defines the powers of the monarch.

words.definition: A system of government in which priests rule in the name of God or a god.
sentences: Ancient Egypt was a form of theocracy.
In a theocracy, religious laws are supreme.
Iran is an example of a modern theocracy.

words.definition: A system of government that is centralized and dictatorial and requires complete subservience to the state.
sentences: Totalitarianism controls all aspects of people's lives.
North Korea is often described as a totalitarian state.
Freedom is absent under totalitarianism.

words.definition: A form of government characterized by strong central power and limited political freedoms.
sentences: Authoritarianism often suppresses opposition.
The country moved towards authoritarianism.
Under authoritarianism, individual rights are restricted.

words.definition: Government by the wealthy.
sentences: Some critics argue that certain societies are plutocracies.
In a plutocracy, rich people hold the power.
The idea of a plutocracy is often seen negatively.

words.definition: A system in which promotion is based on individual ability or achievement rather than on wealth or social position.
sentences: A true meritocracy rewards hard work and talent.
Many people believe in the ideal of a meritocracy.
The company aimed to create a meritocracy.

words.definition: The highest class in certain societies, especially those holding hereditary titles or offices.
sentences: The aristocracy held most of the power in old times.
Members of the aristocracy often had special privileges.
The French Revolution challenged the aristocracy.

words.definition: A system of government in which most of the important decisions are made by state officials rather than by elected representatives.
sentences: Dealing with government bureaucracy can be slow.
The large bureaucracy had many rules.
He found the bureaucracy frustrating.

words.definition: The permanent professional branches of a government's administration, excluding military and judicial branches and elected politicians.
sentences: She works in the civil service.
The civil service ensures the smooth running of government.
Civil service jobs are often stable.

words.definition: The part of the economy that is controlled by the government.
sentences: Healthcare is often part of the public sector.
Many jobs are available in the public sector.
The public sector provides essential services.

words.definition: The part of the economy that is run by private individuals and companies, not the government.
sentences: Most businesses belong to the private sector.
The private sector aims to make a profit.
He moved from the public sector to the private sector.

words.definition: The transfer of a major branch of industry or commerce from private to state ownership or control.
sentences: The government announced the nationalization of the railways.
Nationalization can be controversial.
Some industries underwent nationalization after the war.

words.definition: The transfer of a business, industry, or service from public to private ownership and control.
sentences: The government is considering privatization of state-owned companies.
Privatization can lead to more efficiency.
Many public services have undergone privatization.

words.definition: Government policy regarding taxation and public spending.
sentences: The government uses fiscal policy to manage the economy.
Changes in fiscal policy can affect inflation.
They debated the new fiscal policy.

words.definition: Government policy that controls the supply of money, often through interest rates.
sentences: The central bank sets monetary policy.
Monetary policy aims to keep prices stable.
Interest rate changes are part of monetary policy.

words.definition: A general increase in prices and fall in the purchasing value of money.
sentences: High inflation makes goods more expensive.
The government tries to control inflation.
Inflation can reduce people's savings.

words.definition: A period of temporary economic decline during which trade and industrial activity are reduced.
sentences: The country entered a recession after the financial crisis.
Many people lost jobs during the recession.
Governments try to avoid a recession.

words.definition: A long and severe recession in an economy or market.
sentences: The Great Depression was a very difficult time.
A depression involves high unemployment.
The economy sank into a deep depression.

words.definition: The total value of goods and services produced in a country in one year.
sentences: GDP is a measure of a country's economic health.
The country's GDP grew by 3% last year.
A higher GDP often means a stronger economy.

words.definition: The action of buying and selling goods and services.
sentences: International trade is important for many countries.
They discussed fair trade policies.
Trade agreements can boost economies.

words.definition: To send goods or services to another country for sale.
sentences: The country exports a lot of oil.
Their main export is coffee.
They increased their export volume.

words.definition: To bring goods or services into a country from abroad for sale.
sentences: We import many products from China.
The country relies heavily on food imports.
New taxes were placed on certain imports.

words.definition: The theory or practice of shielding a country's domestic industries from foreign competition by taxing imports.
sentences: Some argue for protectionism to save local jobs.
Protectionism can lead to higher prices for consumers.
The debate between free trade and protectionism is old.

words.definition: International trade left to its natural course without tariffs, quotas, or other restrictions.
sentences: Advocates of free trade believe it boosts economies.
The agreement promoted free trade between the nations.
Free trade can lead to cheaper goods.

words.definition: A sum of money granted by the government or a public body to assist an industry or business so that the price of a commodity or service may remain low or competitive.
sentences: The government provided a subsidy to farmers.
Subsidies can help new industries grow.
They debated whether to give a subsidy to the company.

words.definition: Help, assistance, or support, especially financial or humanitarian.
sentences: Many countries provide foreign aid to developing nations.
Humanitarian aid was sent to the disaster zone.
The aid helped rebuild the damaged city.

words.definition: Money that is owed or due.
sentences: The country has a large national debt.
He worked hard to pay off his debt.
Many nations are burdened by foreign debt.

words.definition: The amount by which something, especially a sum of money, is too small.
sentences: The budget deficit increased last year.
A trade deficit means a country imports more than it exports.
Reducing the deficit is a government priority.

words.definition: An amount of something left over when requirements have been met; an excess of production or supply over demand.
sentences: The country had a budget surplus this year.
There was a surplus of food after the harvest.
A trade surplus means a country exports more than it imports.

words.definition: The system of taxing people or companies.
sentences: Taxation is how governments raise money.
They discussed reforms to the taxation system.
High taxation can affect economic growth.

words.definition: Income, especially when of a company or organization and of a substantial nature.
sentences: The government's main revenue comes from taxes.
The company's revenue increased last quarter.
New policies aim to boost national revenue.

words.definition: The action of spending funds.
sentences: Government expenditure on education increased.
They reviewed their monthly expenditure.
Reducing unnecessary expenditure is important.

words.definition: Organized public or private social services for the assistance of disadvantaged groups.
sentences: Social welfare programs help those in need.
Many countries have strong social welfare systems.
They debated the future of social welfare.

words.definition: The organized provision of medical care to individuals or a community.
sentences: Access to good healthcare is a basic right.
The government is improving public healthcare.
Healthcare costs can be very high.

words.definition: The process of receiving or giving systematic instruction, especially at a school or university.
sentences: Education is key to a country's development.
She believes in free education for all.
Investment in education benefits society.

words.definition: Buses, trains, and other forms of transport that are available to the public, charged for, and run on fixed routes.
sentences: Many people use public transport to get to work.
Investing in public transport can reduce traffic.
The city has excellent public transport.

words.definition: The planning and design of cities and towns.
sentences: Good urban planning creates livable cities.
Urban planning considers traffic, parks, and housing.
The new district was a result of careful urban planning.

words.definition: The process of improving the quality of life and economic well-being of people living in rural areas.
sentences: The project focuses on rural development.
Rural development aims to create jobs in the countryside.
Investment is needed for rural development.

words.definition: Statistical data relating to the population and particular groups within it.
sentences: The demographics of the country are changing rapidly.
Demographics show an aging population.
Businesses study demographics to understand their customers.

words.definition: An official count or survey of a population, typically recording various details of individuals.
sentences: A national census is conducted every ten years.
The census helps the government plan services.
The census provides important population data.

words.definition: All the inhabitants of a particular town, area, or country.
sentences: The world population is still growing.
The city's population has increased.
They studied the population trends.

words.definition: The movement of people from one place to another to live.
sentences: There has been a lot of migration to the cities.
Economic reasons often cause migration.
Bird migration happens every year.

words.definition: The protection granted by a state to someone who has left their native country as a political refugee.
sentences: He applied for political asylum.
Seeking asylum is a human right.
The country granted asylum to many fleeing war.

words.definition: The action of moving something or someone from their usual or proper place.
sentences: The war caused mass displacement of people.
Natural disasters can lead to large-scale displacement.
They are working to help displaced families.

words.definition: The dispersion of any people from their original homeland.
sentences: The Irish diaspora is spread across the world.
Many cultures have a diaspora.
The diaspora maintains ties with their homeland.

words.definition: The policy or practice of acquiring full or partial political control over another country, occupying it with settlers, and exploiting it economically.
sentences: Colonialism had a lasting impact on many nations.
The history of colonialism is complex and often painful.
Many countries fought to end colonialism.

words.definition: A system where individuals are treated as property and forced to work.
sentences: Slavery was abolished in many countries in the 19th century.
The history of slavery is a dark chapter.
Modern slavery still exists in some forms.

words.definition: A person who supported the ending of slavery.
sentences: Harriet Tubman was a famous abolitionist.
Abolitionists worked tirelessly for freedom.
The abolitionist movement gained strength.

words.definition: A woman seeking the right to vote through organized protest.
sentences: Suffragettes marched for women's voting rights.
The suffragette movement was powerful.
Emmeline Pankhurst was a leading suffragette.

words.definition: The rights of citizens to political and social freedom and equality.
sentences: The Civil Rights Movement fought for equality for all.
Civil rights protect individuals from discrimination.
Martin Luther King Jr. was a civil rights leader.

words.definition: The enforced separation of different racial groups in a country, community, or establishment.
sentences: Racial segregation was common in the past.
The civil rights movement fought to end segregation.
Segregation denied people equal opportunities.

words.definition: The unjust or prejudicial treatment of different categories of people or things, especially on the grounds of race, age, or sex.
sentences: Discrimination based on race is illegal.
They faced discrimination in the workplace.
Laws aim to prevent discrimination.

words.definition: Preconceived opinion that is not based on reason or actual experience.
sentences: Prejudice can lead to unfair treatment.
It's important to overcome prejudice.
Education can help reduce prejudice.

words.definition: A widely held but fixed and oversimplified image or idea of a particular type of person or thing.
sentences: It's wrong to judge people based on stereotypes.
The movie used many harmful stereotypes.
Breaking stereotypes helps us understand others better.

words.definition: The state of being diverse; variety.
sentences: Diversity in the workplace brings new ideas.
The city is known for its cultural diversity.
Embracing diversity makes a society stronger.

words.definition: The practice or policy of providing equal access to opportunities and resources for people who might otherwise be excluded or marginalized.
sentences: The school promotes inclusion for all students.
Inclusion means everyone feels welcome.
They worked towards greater inclusion in society.

words.definition: The quality of being fair and impartial.
sentences: They strive for equity in education.
Equity means giving everyone what they need to succeed.
The new policy aims to promote social equity.

words.definition: Justice in terms of the distribution of wealth, opportunities, and privileges within a society.
sentences: Many activists fight for social justice.
Social justice aims to create a fair society.
The movement advocates for social justice reforms.

words.definition: The policy or action of using vigorous campaigning to bring about political or social change.
sentences: Youth activism is growing worldwide.
Her life was dedicated to activism.
Activism can lead to significant change.

words.definition: An organized effort to bring about social or political change through public demonstrations and other forms of protest.
sentences: The protest movement gained widespread support.
Many people joined the protest movement.
The protest movement aimed to raise awareness.

words.definition: A public meeting or march protesting against something or expressing views on a political issue.
sentences: Thousands attended the peaceful demonstration.
The demonstration was held outside the parliament.
Police monitored the demonstration closely.

words.definition: A mass meeting of people making a political protest or showing support for a cause.
sentences: They organized a rally for climate action.
The presidential candidate held a large rally.
The rally brought together many supporters.

words.definition: A formal written request, typically one signed by many people, appealing to authority with respect to a particular cause.
sentences: They started a petition to save the park.
Thousands signed the online petition.
The petition was presented to the city council.

words.definition: The act of trying to influence decisions made by officials in the government.
sentences: Environmental groups engage in lobbying.
Lobbying can influence new laws.
The company spent a lot on lobbying efforts.

words.definition: The ordinary people regarded as the main body of an organization or the public at large.
sentences: The campaign started as a grassroots effort.
Grassroots movements often begin locally.
They built support from the grassroots level.

words.definition: False information, which is intended to mislead.
sentences: The spread of disinformation is a serious problem.
They tried to counter the disinformation campaign.
Disinformation can harm public trust.

words.definition: False or inaccurate information, especially that which is intended to deceive.
sentences: There's a lot of misinformation online.
It's important to check facts to avoid misinformation.
Misinformation can spread quickly.

words.definition: A belief that some covert but influential organization is responsible for a circumstance or event.
sentences: He believes in many conspiracy theories.
Conspiracy theories often lack evidence.
The internet has helped spread conspiracy theories.

words.definition: The right to express one's opinions publicly without censorship or restraint.
sentences: Freedom of speech is a fundamental human right.
They protested for freedom of speech.
This right allows people to share their views openly.

words.definition: The principle that all people and institutions are subject to and accountable to law that is fairly applied and enforced.
sentences: The rule of law ensures fairness and order.
No one is above the rule of law.
The rule of law is essential for a stable society.

words.definition: The division of a state's government into branches, each with separate and independent powers and responsibilities.
sentences: The separation of powers prevents too much power in one place.
The US government has a separation of powers.
This system includes legislative, executive, and judicial branches.

words.definition: A system in which the different parts of a government have powers that affect and control the other parts so that no part can become too powerful.
sentences: Checks and balances ensure no branch becomes too strong.
The system of checks and balances protects democracy.
The constitution includes checks and balances.

words.definition: A system of government in which power is divided between a central authority and constituent political units.
sentences: India operates under a federal system.
A federal system allows for regional differences.
The federal system balances power.

words.definition: The method by which votes are translated into seats in a legislature.
sentences: Different countries have different electoral systems.
The electoral system determines how leaders are chosen.
They debated reforms to the electoral system.

words.definition: An electoral system in which parties gain seats in proportion to the number of votes cast for them.
sentences: Proportional representation aims for fairer outcomes.
Many European countries use proportional representation.
This system ensures smaller parties can win seats.

words.definition: An electoral system in which the candidate who achieves the most votes in a given constituency wins.
sentences: The UK uses a first-past-the-post system.
First-past-the-post can lead to two-party dominance.
In this system, you only need one more vote than anyone else.

words.definition: Manipulate the boundaries of (an electoral constituency) so as to favor one party or class.
sentences: Gerrymandering can unfairly influence election results.
The court ruled against the gerrymandering of districts.
It's a controversial practice in politics.

words.definition: A body of voters in a specified area who elect a representative to a legislative body.
sentences: Each member of parliament represents a constituency.
She campaigned hard in her constituency.
The constituency includes several towns.

words.definition: A building where people go to vote in an election.
sentences: Voters lined up at the polling station.
The polling station opened early in the morning.
You cast your vote at the polling station.

words.definition: A process of voting, in writing and typically in secret.
sentences: She cast her ballot for the new leader.
The ballot listed all the candidates.
The results were counted after all ballots were in.

words.definition: An organized course of action to achieve a goal, especially a political or commercial one.
sentences: The candidate ran a strong election campaign.
They launched a campaign to raise awareness.
The campaign involved many public speeches.

words.definition: A public declaration of policy and aims, especially one issued before an election by a political party or candidate.
sentences: The party's manifesto outlined their plans for the country.
He published his manifesto before the election.
The manifesto covered many important issues.

words.definition: A formal discussion on a particular topic in a public meeting or legislative assembly, in which opposing arguments are put forward.
sentences: The candidates held a televised debate.
Parliament held a long debate on the new law.
It's important to have a healthy debate of ideas.

words.definition: Performed by or affecting only one person, group, or country involved in a situation, without the agreement of another or the others.
sentences: The country made a unilateral decision.
Unilateral actions can sometimes cause tension.
They preferred a multilateral approach over a unilateral one.

words.definition: Involving more than two countries or groups.
sentences: The agreement was a result of multilateral negotiations.
Multilateral cooperation is essential for global issues.
The UN promotes multilateral diplomacy.

words.definition: Politics, especially international relations, as influenced by geographical factors.
sentences: Geopolitics plays a big role in global conflicts.
Studying geopolitics helps understand world events.
The region's geopolitics are very complex.

words.definition: The study of the relationships between different countries.
sentences: She studies international relations at university.
Good international relations are key to peace.
The conflict strained international relations.

words.definition: The political interaction of transnational actors aimed at solving problems that affect more than one state or region.
sentences: Global governance addresses issues like climate change.
The United Nations is an example of global governance.
Effective global governance requires cooperation.

words.definition: Material or logistical assistance provided for humanitarian purposes, typically in response to a humanitarian crisis.
sentences: Humanitarian aid was rushed to the earthquake victims.
Many organizations provide humanitarian aid.
The convoy carried vital humanitarian aid.

words.definition: A non-profit organization that operates independently of any government.
sentences: Many NGOs work on environmental issues.
She volunteers for an international NGO.
NGOs play a crucial role in disaster relief.

words.definition: An international organization formed to promote international cooperation and to achieve peace and security.
sentences: The United Nations tries to solve global problems.
Delegates from many countries meet at the United Nations.
The United Nations was founded after World War II.

words.definition: The most powerful body of the United Nations, responsible for maintaining international peace and security.
sentences: The UN Security Council passed a resolution.
Five permanent members sit on the Security Council.
The Security Council can impose sanctions.

words.definition: The main deliberative, policymaking, and representative organ of the United Nations.
sentences: All UN member states are represented in the General Assembly.
The General Assembly discusses global issues.
The resolution was adopted by the General Assembly.

words.definition: A body of rules established by custom or treaty and recognized by nations as binding in their relations with one another.
sentences: International law governs relations between countries.
Violating international law can lead to sanctions.
The court interprets international law.

words.definition: Actions carried out during a war that violate accepted international rules of warfare.
sentences: He was accused of committing war crimes.
War crimes are prosecuted by international courts.
The investigation uncovered evidence of war crimes.

words.definition: A situation involving a large number of people who have been forced to leave their homes and seek safety elsewhere.
sentences: The conflict led to a severe refugee crisis.
The international community responded to the refugee crisis.
Addressing the refugee crisis requires global effort.

words.definition: A single event or a series of events that are threatening in terms of health, safety or well-being of a community or large group of people.
sentences: The drought caused a humanitarian crisis.
Humanitarian crisis situations require urgent aid.
The organization sent teams to respond to the humanitarian crisis.

words.definition: The preservation of peace, especially between hostile groups, by international military forces.
sentences: UN forces are involved in peacekeeping missions.
Peacekeeping operations aim to prevent further conflict.
The soldiers were deployed for peacekeeping duties.

words.definition: A competition between nations for superiority in the development and accumulation of weapons.
sentences: The Cold War involved an intense arms race.
An arms race can lead to increased global tension.
They tried to prevent a new arms race.

words.definition: The reduction or withdrawal of military forces and weapons.
sentences: The treaty called for nuclear disarmament.
Disarmament is a goal for many peace activists.
They discussed plans for global disarmament.

words.definition: The prevention of an increase in the number of countries possessing nuclear weapons.
sentences: The treaty focuses on nuclear non-proliferation.
Non-proliferation efforts aim for a safer world.
They discussed strategies for non-proliferation.

words.definition: Intervention in a dispute to resolve it; arbitration.
sentences: The UN offered mediation to resolve the conflict.
Mediation helped the two parties reach an agreement.
They sought mediation to settle their differences.

words.definition: A group of countries or political parties that have formed an alliance for a common purpose.
sentences: The economic bloc aimed to promote trade.
The former Soviet bloc dissolved.
Many countries joined the regional bloc.

words.definition: The lines separating two countries, states, or other political areas.
sentences: The soldiers guarded the borders.
Many people cross the borders every day.
The dispute was about the country's borders.

words.definition: An area of land under the jurisdiction of a ruler or state.
sentences: The country expanded its territory.
The disputed territory caused conflict.
Animals defend their territory.

words.definition: A policy of extending a country's power and influence through colonization, use of military force, or other means.
sentences: Imperialism led to large empires.
The age of imperialism saw European powers expand.
Critics argue against modern forms of imperialism.

words.definition: Love for one's country and a willingness to defend it.
sentences: His patriotism was clear in his actions.
Singing the national anthem shows patriotism.
Patriotism is a feeling of loyalty to your nation.

words.definition: Supreme power or authority; the authority of a state to govern itself.
sentences: The country declared its sovereignty.
National sovereignty is a key principle in international law.
They fought to protect their sovereignty.

words.definition: The process by which a country determines its own statehood and forms its own government.
sentences: The people fought for self-determination.
The principle of self-determination is important for nations.
They demanded the right to self-determination.

words.definition: The control of a country or area by a foreign military force.
sentences: The country remained under foreign occupation for years.
The occupation ended after the peace treaty.
Resistance movements fought against the occupation.

words.definition: A body of troops stationed in a particular place to defend it.
sentences: The old fort still houses a small garrison.
The garrison was prepared for an attack.
A large garrison protected the city.

words.definition: A military operation in which enemy forces surround a town or building, cutting off essential supplies, with the aim of compelling the surrender of those inside.
sentences: The city was under siege for months.
The siege caused great suffering to the people.
They broke the siege and relieved the city.

words.definition: A sustained fight between large organized armed forces.
sentences: The battle was long and bloody.
Many soldiers fought in the famous battle.
The battle changed the course of the war.

words.definition: An agreement made by opposing sides in a war to stop fighting for a certain time; a truce.
sentences: The two sides signed an armistice.
The armistice brought a temporary end to the fighting.
Armistice Day marks the end of World War I.

words.definition: A temporary suspension of fighting, typically one agreed upon by all sides.
sentences: The UN called for an immediate ceasefire.
A ceasefire was declared to allow aid to pass.
The ceasefire was broken after only a few hours.

words.definition: An agreement between enemies or opponents to stop fighting or arguing for a certain time.
sentences: They agreed to a temporary truce.
The truce allowed time for negotiations.
The fighting stopped during the Christmas truce.

words.definition: The restoration of friendly relations.
sentences: The leaders worked towards reconciliation after the conflict.
Reconciliation is important for healing a nation.
They sought reconciliation with their former enemies.

words.definition: A person who has served in the military.
sentences: Many veterans attended the parade.
The organization supports veterans.
He is a veteran of the Vietnam War.

words.definition: Compulsory enlistment for state service, typically into the armed forces.
sentences: Some countries still have conscription.
Conscription was introduced during the war.
He avoided conscription by moving abroad.

words.definition: A military force that is raised from the civil population to supplement a regular army in an emergency.
sentences: The local militia defended the town.
The militia was called up to help with the crisis.
They trained with the militia every weekend.

words.definition: A form of irregular warfare in which small groups of combatants use military tactics including ambushes, sabotage, raids, petty warfare, hit-and-run tactics, and mobility to fight a larger, less-mobile traditional army.
sentences: The rebels used guerrilla warfare tactics.
Guerrilla warfare is often fought by smaller forces.
They were experts in guerrilla warfare.

words.definition: A rebel or revolutionary.
sentences: The government fought against the insurgents.
Insurgent groups controlled parts of the region.
The insurgent leader called for a ceasefire.

words.definition: A person who rises in opposition or armed resistance against an established government or ruler.
sentences: The rebels took control of the city.
He was a rebel against the system.
The rebel forces gained ground.

words.definition: Involving or causing a complete or dramatic change; a person who advocates or engages in political revolution.
sentences: The revolutionary ideas changed society.
He was a revolutionary leader.
The new technology was revolutionary.

words.definition: The unlawful use of violence and intimidation, especially against civilians, in the pursuit of political aims.
sentences: Governments work together to fight terrorism.
Terrorism aims to create fear and instability.
The attack was an act of terrorism.

words.definition: Holding extreme political or religious views.
sentences: Extremism can lead to violence.
The group was known for its extremism.
Governments try to counter extremism.

words.definition: The beliefs or actions of people who advocate thorough or complete political or social reform.
sentences: Radicalism often seeks fundamental changes.
His early political views were marked by radicalism.
The government worried about the rise of radicalism.

words.definition: A political philosophy that favors traditional values and institutions and is generally against rapid change.
sentences: Conservatism often emphasizes individual responsibility.
The party is known for its conservatism.
He voted for the candidate who represented conservatism.

words.definition: A political philosophy based on belief in progress, the essential goodness of the human race, and the autonomy of the individual and standing for the protection of political and civil liberties.
sentences: Liberalism supports individual freedoms and equality.
The party's platform is based on liberalism.
She believes in the principles of liberalism.

words.definition: A political outlook or position that involves acceptance or support of a balance of social equality and social hierarchy, while opposing political changes that would result in a significant shift of society intensely to the left or right.
sentences: The new party aimed for centrism.
Centrism tries to find common ground.
He is known for his political centrism.

words.definition: A system of ideas and ideals, especially one that forms the basis of economic or political theory and policy.
sentences: Every political party has its own ideology.
His actions were guided by a strong ideology.
The conflict was fueled by opposing ideologies.

words.definition: The art of effective or persuasive speaking or writing, especially the use of figures of speech and other compositional techniques.
sentences: The politician's rhetoric was very powerful.
His speech was full of empty rhetoric.
They analyzed the rhetoric used in the debate.

words.definition: Political activity or practices that seek to win favor by appealing to the desires and prejudices of ordinary people.
sentences: The leader was accused of demagoguery.
Demagoguery can be dangerous for democracy.
He warned against the rise of demagoguery.

words.definition: A political approach that appeals to ordinary people who feel that their concerns are disregarded by established elite groups.
sentences: Populism often involves a focus on the common person.
The rise of populism has changed politics.
He used populist rhetoric in his speeches.

words.definition: The existing power structure in society; the dominant group or elite.
sentences: The protest was against the political establishment.
He challenged the establishment's views.
The establishment resisted change.

words.definition: Excessive bureaucracy or adherence to rules and formalities, especially in public business.
sentences: Getting the permit involved a lot of red tape.
They tried to cut down on government red tape.
Red tape can slow down progress.

words.definition: A person who tries to influence decisions made by officials in the government.
sentences: The lobbyist represented the industry's interests.
Lobbyists try to persuade politicians.
He works as a lobbyist for a charity.

words.definition: A body of experts providing advice and ideas on political, economic, or social problems.
sentences: The think tank published a new report on education.
Many politicians consult with think tanks.
She works for a leading policy think tank.

words.definition: An organization that uses its surplus revenues to achieve its goals rather than distributing them as profit or dividends.
sentences: She volunteers for a local non-profit organization.
Non-profit organizations often focus on social causes.
The non-profit organization helps the homeless.

words.definition: An organization set up to provide help and raise money for those in need.
sentences: He donates regularly to charity.
The charity helps children in poverty.
They organized an event to raise money for charity.

words.definition: The desire to promote the welfare of others, expressed especially by the generous donation of money to good causes.
sentences: His philanthropy has helped many schools.
Philanthropy plays a big role in social development.
She is known for her philanthropy.

words.definition: The policy or action of using vigorous campaigning to bring about political or social change.
sentences: Youth activism is growing worldwide.
Her life was dedicated to activism.
Activism can lead to significant change.

words.definition: Public support for or recommendation of a particular cause or policy.
sentences: The group is involved in advocacy for human rights.
Her advocacy led to new laws.
He is known for his strong advocacy for the poor.

words.definition: The ordinary people regarded as the main body of an organization or the public at large.
sentences: The campaign started as a grassroots effort.
Grassroots movements often begin locally.
They built support from the grassroots level.

words.definition: A direct vote of all the members of an electorate on an important public question.
sentences: The government held a plebiscite on the border dispute.
A plebiscite is similar to a referendum.
The plebiscite showed strong public support.

words.definition: The authority to carry out a policy or course of action, given by the electorate to a candidate or party.
sentences: The election gave the new government a strong mandate.
They believe they have a mandate from the people.
The UN issued a mandate for peacekeeping.

words.definition: An action such as a prolonged speech that obstructs progress in a legislative assembly while not technically contravening the required procedures.
sentences: The senator used a filibuster to delay the vote.
A filibuster can prevent a bill from passing.
The longest filibuster lasted for many hours.

words.definition: Involving the agreement or cooperation of two political parties.
sentences: The bill received bipartisan support.
They hoped for a bipartisan solution to the problem.
Bipartisan efforts are important for progress.

words.definition: An agreement or a settlement of a dispute that is reached by each side making concessions.
sentences: They reached a compromise after long discussions.
Compromise is essential in politics.
Both sides had to make a compromise.

words.definition: A thing that is granted, especially in response to demands; a thing conceded.
sentences: The government made a concession to the protesters.
Each side offered a concession during negotiations.
The company made a major concession to its employees.

words.definition: A temporary alliance for combined action, especially of political parties.
sentences: The two parties formed a coalition government.
The environmental groups formed a coalition.
The coalition aimed to achieve a shared goal.

words.definition: A political party or group that is against the government in power.
sentences: The opposition criticized the new policy.
The leader of the opposition spoke in parliament.
The opposition party wants to win the next election.

words.definition: A person who opposes official policy, especially that of an authoritarian state.
sentences: Many dissidents were imprisoned for their views.
The dissident spoke out against the regime.
She became a well-known dissident.

words.definition: A person who rises in opposition or armed resistance against an established government or ruler.
sentences: The rebels took control of the city.
He was a rebel against the system.
The rebel forces gained ground.

words.definition: Belief in the abolition of all government and the organization of society on a voluntary, cooperative basis without recourse to force or compulsion.
sentences: Anarchism suggests a society without rulers.
Some people believe in anarchism as an ideal.
The philosophy of anarchism has various forms.

words.definition: A political philosophy, movement, or regime that exalts nation and often race above the individual and that stands for a centralized autocratic government headed by a dictatorial leader, severe economic and social regimentation, and forcible suppression of opposition.
sentences: Fascism rose to power in Europe in the 20th century.
Mussolini's Italy was a fascist state.
Fascism is characterized by extreme nationalism.

words.definition: The political principles of the National Socialist German Workers' Party.
sentences: Nazism led to World War II and the Holocaust.
The ideology of Nazism promoted racial hatred.
The defeat of Nazism was a global effort.

words.definition: A war between groups of people in the same country.
sentences: The American Civil War was fought over slavery.
Many families were divided during the civil war.
A civil war can cause great destruction.

words.definition: Close observation, especially of a suspected spy or criminal.
sentences: Government surveillance can raise privacy concerns.
The police kept the suspect under surveillance.
CCTV cameras are used for public surveillance.

words.definition: A sudden, big change, often in government, caused by people fighting.
sentences: The American Revolution led to independence.
Many people died during the revolution.
The invention of the internet caused a technology revolution.

words.definition: An attempt to put an end to the authority of a person or body by rebelling.
sentences: The people decided to revolt against the harsh ruler.
The peasants' revolt was quickly put down.
News of the revolt spread quickly.

words.definition: An active revolt or uprising.
sentences: The government faced a growing insurgency.
The insurgency aimed to overthrow the regime.
Fighting continued as the insurgency gained strength.

words.definition: An act of open, armed resistance to an established government or ruler.
sentences: The rebellion against the king failed.
Many people joined the rebellion.
The rebellion sought to overthrow the government.

words.definition: A political theory derived from Karl Marx, advocating class war and leading to a society in which all property is publicly owned and each person works and is paid according to their abilities and needs.
sentences: Some countries historically adopted communism.
In theory, communism aims for a classless society.
The fall of the Berlin Wall marked a decline in communism.

words.definition: The holding or expression of opinions at variance with those commonly or officially held.
sentences: There was some dissent within the party.
She expressed her dissent openly.
The government tried to suppress dissent.
